metadata.case_name: Enquiry Cum Reservation Clerks v. General Manager, Northern Railway & Railway Board

facts.text: Petitions under Article 226 of the Constitution raising common questions of law and fact, to be considered in a common judgment.
Petitioners are serving as Enquiry Cum Reservation Clerks in the Northern Railway.

Petitioners seek writ of mandamus to Respondent No.1 (General Manager, Northern Railway) to withdraw order dated November 3, 1965 (No. 754E/20-II Trip EIC) and restore names in panel as shown in Annexure E for promotions.
Petitioners seek writ of mandamus to Respondent No.2 (Railway Board) to withdraw directions to partially cancel panel in Annexure E.

Railway Board communication No. E NG 63 PMI-52 dated February 29, 1964 prescribed channel of promotion for Enquiry Cum Reservation Clerks: 25% higher grade posts; in every 20 posts: 15 Enquiry Cum Reservation Clerks (Rs.150-240), 2 Assistant Reservation Supervisors (Rs.205-280 non-selection), 2 Reservation Supervisors (Rs.250-380 selection), 1 Chief Reservation Inspector (Rs.370-475 selection).

General Manager, Northern Railway sanctioned upgrading of posts from 1-4-1964: 11 posts CRI (Rs.370-475), 18 posts Reservation Supervisor (Rs.250-380), 26 posts Assistant Reservation Supervisor (Rs.205-280) (Annexure B).

Railway Board letter No. E NG 62 PMI/91 dated July 10, 1964 prescribed procedure for non-gazetted selection posts: panel size = existing + anticipated vacancies + 25% for unforeseen; anticipated only normal wastage; currency 2 years or till exhausted.

General Manager, Northern Railway communication dated January 22, 1965 to Divisional Superintendents: selection for Reservation Supervisor (Rs.250-380); written test on 13-2-1965; interviews thereafter; based on provisional seniority lists.
Written tests held on 13-2-1965 as prescribed.

Selection Committee selected 38 persons including petitioners; panel published in Northern Railway Gazette on August 1, 1965; petitioners ranked 25 or below; retention subject to satisfactory work; no right to permanent absorption.
Senior staff not selected agitated mode of promotion; questions in Parliament.

Railway Board confidential letter to General Manager, Northern Railway: incorrect procedure followed; should fill initial grades first; panel should be 24 (18 upgraded +1 retirement +5 contingencies=24), field of choice 24x4=96 not 152; operate first 24, delete remaining 14; then select for higher grades.
General Manager communication (Annexure T): panel of 38 operated up to first 24 persons; remaining 14 deleted; dated around November 1965.
Names of petitioners (ranked 25 or below) removed from panel.
Petitioners' efforts to withdraw GM communication failed.
Petitioners allege Railway Board directed partial cancellation under political pressure; GM disagreed but obeyed.
Respondents deny mala fides; allegation unsubstantiated.

legal_issues.text: Whether the order of General Manager dated November 3, 1965 removing petitioners' names from panel is liable to be quashed on grounds of mala fides or political pressure.
Whether Railway Board's interpretation of 'normal wastage' in its letter dated July 10, 1964 is erroneous.
Whether Railway Board's direction selectively applied only to Northern Railway violates Article 14.
Whether petitioners acquired legal right to promotion by inclusion in panel.
Whether Railway Board's letter dated July 10, 1964 has statutory force and whether Board could interpret it.
Whether principles of natural justice violated by not hearing petitioners before removal from panel.

petitioner_arguments.text: Railway Board compelled by political pressure to direct partial cancellation of panel despite GM's correct interpretation of 'normal wastage'.
Railway Board's interpretation of 'normal wastage' erroneous; GM's interpretation correct and followed by other GMs.
Railway Board's direction confined to Northern Railway, discriminating against it compared to other railways and departments, violating Article 14.
Principles of natural justice violated as petitioners not heard before impugned order.

respondent_arguments.text: Petitioners not aggrieved as panel inclusion gave no legal right, only chance for promotion; Gazette stated no right to permanent absorption.
Railway Board best authority to interpret its term 'normal wastage'; interpretation not unsustainable.
No discrimination; direction due to complaints about Northern Railway's panel; interpretation of general application.
Railway Board's letter statutory under Rule 157 IRE Code; executive power to interpret.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 157 Indian Railway Establishment Code Vol I, Article 309

respondent_arguments.text: No hearing required as executive action, not judicial.

court_reasoning.text: No satisfactory proof of mala fides; allegations vague and denied.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plea of mala fides easy to advance but difficult to establish.

court_reasoning.text: 'Normal wastage' coined by Railway Board; Board best to interpret; not wholly unsustainable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Railway Board is the best authority to say what it meant.

court_reasoning.text: No material showing discrimination between railways; direction due to complaints in Northern Railway.
Panel inclusion qualified for promotion but no legal right or entitlement; mere expectancy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Placing names in panel only qualified them for promotion. It did not entitle them for promotion.

court_reasoning.text: Railway Board letter dated July 10, 1964 is rule under Rule 157 IRE Code (Article 309); executive power, Board can interpret unless mala fide.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order could have been made under Rule 157.

court_reasoning.text: No natural justice required for executive action; cases cited inapplicable as not judicial power.

holdings.text: No legal right acquired by panel inclusion; only expectancy till promotion.
Railway Board has power to interpret its own executive orders unless mala fide.
No violation of Article 14 or natural justice.
Petitions not maintainable as no legal right aggrieved.

precedents_cited.case_name: Balakrishnan v. Deputy Inspector General of Police
precedents_cited.relevance: Supports no legal right from panel inclusion.
Railway Board orders have statutory force under Rule 157.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Police, Bombay v. Gordhandas
precedents_cited.relevance: Rule on discretion not attracted as no discretion given to GM.

precedents_cited.case_name: Strawboard Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. Gutta Mill Workers Union
precedents_cited.relevance: No relevance; functus officio not applicable.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petitions; equality; power to frame rules.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Railway Establishment Code, Volume I
statutes_cited.relevance: Railway Board power to make rules for non-gazetted servants; impugned order not under Rule 158.

outcome.summary: The writ petitions challenging the removal of petitioners' names from the promotion panel are dismissed for lack of legal right, no mala fides, correct interpretation by Railway Board, no discrimination or natural justice violation.

key_quotes.text: A plea of mala fides is easy to advance but difficult to establish.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The placing of the names of the petitioners in the panel only qualified them for promotion. It did not entitle them for promotion.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on no legal right.

key_quotes.text: The Railway Board is the best authority to say what it meant by that expression.
key_quotes.speaker: court
